my:Hazard.my:Description: Crew safety, damage to vessel and equipment
my:Hazard.my:ControlMeasures: a) High consideration to adverse environmental factors such as winds, sea and swell, other limitations or restrictions should be given. b) Crew should comply with the ship's plans. SOLAS training manual and IAMSAR Volume III must be referred to during the planning stages of recovery. c) Detailed briefing of all crew involved in the recovery operations must be carried out including training/familiarisation of normal and emergency launching and recovery operation. d) Effective communication on board, with rescue coordination (MRCC/In-Scene Coordinator) holds the key to a successful recovery. e) Risk assessments of Launch/Recovery of FFB,RB and life raft's should be consulted. f) Fibre-light Cradle which is fitted in Rescue Boats should be used for the recovery of persons in water. g) During the recovery, the ship shall manoeuvre so as to provide the best lee possible. h) The Master must remain situationally aware and at no point put the ship at risk or in a position that further endangers the rescue.

a) Use of suitable and appropriate PPE: overalls, safety shoes, hard hat, gloves, lifejackets, immersion suit etc. b) Adequate lighting to be provided, use of portable lighting if necessary should be taken in consideration. c) Trip hazards and any overhead obstructions to be clearly marked. All steps, platforms and deck surface should be clear of any oil and/ or grease residue. c) The crew should not be required to leave the protection of the vessel's safety rails. A life line or safety harness should be worn if there is any risk of falling.

a) It is very likely that the recovered person from water to suffer from hypothermia. To prevent further heat loss the person has to be moved indoors or somewhere warm as soon as possible. Once the person is in a warm environment, carefully remove any wet clothing and fry them. Wrap them in warm blankets, towels or coats, protecting their head and torso first. Encourage the person to shiver if they are capable to do so. Give the person warm drinks (not alcohol) or high-energy foods such as chocolate to help warm them up. But only do this if they can swallow normally. Ask them to cough to see if they can swallow. b) There are few things that should be avoided: Do Not put the cold person into a hot bath, do not massage their limbs, do not use heating lamps, do not give them alcohol to drink. If one of these things happens, it can cause the blood vessels in the arms and legs to open too quickly, and if this happens, it can lead to a dramatic fall in blood pressure to the vital organs such as the brain, heart, lungs and kidneys, potentially resulting in cardiac arrest and death. Please consult Ship's Medical Guide, Cold Water Survival Guide and SOLAS manual Chapter 2.
